summary: Joffrey raises his sword to Lady and Sansa steps right into it and is standing there with a sword pierced through her and crying...
question: Joffrey raises his sword to Lady and Sansa steps right into it and is standing there with a sword pierced through her and crying and holding her dire wolf while Joffrey shits himself?
answer: i like to think that sansa addams!stark would be more like gomez addams’ cheerful disposition mixed with superman’s lack of knowledge when it comes to the kinds of things that actual human people can withstand. so like she makes a fuss about stubbing her toe because she thinks that’s what proper southron ladies would do but if she ever got genuinely injured she’d shrug it off in true addams!stark fashion and not understand why everyone is staring at her in horror

tags: like idk what the sky tower would mean in this case but regardless cat’s reactions to mya are so interesting considering sansa’s arc and
body:
Stone & Snow

Since i’m never certain about anything, i’ll say IF jonsa is endgame and grrm has been sitting on this ending for 2 decades….wow he’s good. I recently started rereading the books and I’m almost done AGoT. This is my first time reading since watching the show and reading all the jonsa theories. And when I got to the chapter where Catelyn arrives in the Eyrie I lost it a little.

We have this entire chapter talking about the three towers Stone, Snow, and Sky. And we see Catelyn thinking of Jon when she is lead by the illegitimate Mya Stone, not knowing that one day her own daughter Sansa will become Alayne Stone, of the Vale. There’s so much Stone and Snow imagery in this chapter I was shocked haha. If it’s relevant and we get a union of Stone & Snow, well GRRM has planned his stuff.

summary: When did u first start liking Sansa? I liked her right from episode 1, I found her amusing and relatable honestly. Like...
question: When did u first start liking Sansa? I liked her right from episode 1, I found her amusing and relatable honestly. Like everyone’s been the spoiled young child at some point, but she snapped out of it instantly.
answer: I liked her, then I was indifferent about her, then I loved her. That all happened in the first season. The first episode of this series was a lot to take in when I first was watching it. There was like hundreds of characters, a lot more nudity than everything else that I watched combined, and most importantly, it was really dark. Children were being flung off towers, teenage girls were being sold to grown men, siblings were getting on with each other, and the list kinda goes on and on. So, after I finished the episode, what was most memorable to me wasn’t any of that, but rather this young girl who had this childish crush on this boy she just met. The normalcy of that instantly made me interested in what was going to her character, and the relationship she was going to have with this prince. I thought they were going to have this major romance that was going to last the whole show at the time. As it turned out, things turned out to be much more gruesome than I expected, and the prince ended up being this sadist who would later become her abuser. Anyways, after my initial impression of her character, nothing in the first season made me dislike Sansa, though I just didn’t understand why she was still into Joffrey after what went down at the Trident. That lack of understanding just caused me to just be indifferent about her character. She didn’t become my favorite character until the last episode of the first season when Joffrey showed Sansa her father’s head. I was surprised when she stood there and told Joffrey that perhaps her brother would give her Joffrey’s head. I was even more surprised when she stayed firmly in place and made no sound despite the fact that an older man was harshly hitting her. I was completely taken aback when she walked towards Joffrey in order to push him off the bridge. I didn’t have any problems with her, but that completely changed my opinion of her character, and made me realize just how strong she actually is. For some reason, after that scene, she always ended up being the character I was the most excited to see again whenever I would watch another episode of the show.

summary: Hi I love your fiction writing, I would like your thoughts on this: I’m bothered that because Jon butt in with “aha...
question: Hi I love your fiction writing, I would like your thoughts on this: I’m bothered that because Jon butt in with “aha ...everything before the word but” we didn’t get to hear what Sansa was going to say. I would like to hear it was some more sense, “they respect you they really do but you need to discuss things before you announce them out loud”?! Or “but, you need to linger a bit longer on your forehead kisses because it wasn’t really long enough #firsttimeifeltsafeinyears” thanks!
answer:
From their interactions in s6, it’s clear he’s told her about what happened to him, why he was murdered, that he’s been resurrected etc. So, I think that was running through her mind. 

When Sansa suggests that the castles should go to new families, loyal families, the gathered lords and ladies agree. She’s not delivering some odd, controversial solution no one’s ever heard of but instead bringing some sense to the table after Royce’s emotional, “Their castles should be torn down with not a stone left standing!”

Jon’s suggestion, however, is controversial. This is not how things usually are done. Even as Jon and Sansa each argue their point, people still agree with her. The castles should go to new families, families of the men who died fighting for Jon. When Jon states that he’s made his decision and his decision is final, no one murmurs or bangs their cups in the table in agreement. At least not until Ned Umber and Alys Karstark swear fealty.

To my modern ears, Jon’s suggestion is better and kinder, but I still understand Sansa’s worry here. Jon has been named king even though he’s a bastard. She knows how quickly loyalties can shift. She knows what happened the last time Jon made a controversial and modern “yesterday’s wars don’t matter anymore and everyone needs to band together” type of decision. He was murdered for it and she doesn’t want that to happen again because she loves him.

So I think she was only about to remind him of how easy it is to lose respect when you make too many unpopular decisions. Which of course also foreshadowed what happened later, when they were unhappy with Jon’s long stay at DS and the lords started wondering whether they should’ve named Sansa queen instead. And it gives us a hint as to how they’ll react when they learn about Jon bending the knee.

Thanks for the ask!

Jon’s suggestion, however, is controversial. This is not how things usually are done. Even as Jon and Sansa each argue their point, people still agree with her. The castles should go to new families, families of the men who died fighting for Jon. When Jon states that he’s made his decision and his decision is final, no one murmurs or bangs their cups in the table in agreement. At least not until Ned Umber and Alys Karstark swear fealty.

To my modern ears, Jon’s suggestion is better and kinder, but I still understand Sansa’s worry here. Jon has been named king even though he’s a bastard. She knows how quickly loyalties can shift. She knows what happened the last time Jon made a controversial and modern “yesterday’s wars don’t matter anymore and everyone needs to band together” type of decision. He was murdered for it and she doesn’t want that to happen again because she loves him.

So I think she was only about to remind him of how easy it is to lose respect when you make too many unpopular decisions. Which of course also foreshadowed what happened later, when they were unhappy with Jon’s long stay at DS and the lords started wondering whether they should’ve named Sansa queen instead. And it gives us a hint as to how they’ll react when they learn about Jon bending the knee.

Thanks for the ask!

trail.content_raw:
From their interactions in s6, it’s clear he’s told her about what happened to him, why he was murdered, that he’s been resurrected etc. So, I think that was running through her mind. 

When Sansa suggests that the castles should go to new families, loyal families, the gathered lords and ladies agree. She’s not delivering some odd, controversial solution no one’s ever heard of but instead bringing some sense to the table after Royce’s emotional, “Their castles should be torn down with not a stone left standing!”

Jon’s suggestion, however, is controversial. This is not how things usually are done. Even as Jon and Sansa each argue their point, people still agree with her. The castles should go to new families, families of the men who died fighting for Jon. When Jon states that he’s made his decision and his decision is final, no one murmurs or bangs their cups in the table in agreement. At least not until Ned Umber and Alys Karstark swear fealty.

To my modern ears, Jon’s suggestion is better and kinder, but I still understand Sansa’s worry here. Jon has been named king even though he’s a bastard. She knows how quickly loyalties can shift. She knows what happened the last time Jon made a controversial and modern “yesterday’s wars don’t matter anymore and everyone needs to band together” type of decision. He was murdered for it and she doesn’t want that to happen again because she loves him.

So I think she was only about to remind him of how easy it is to lose respect when you make too many unpopular decisions. Which of course also foreshadowed what happened later, when they were unhappy with Jon’s long stay at DS and the lords started wondering whether they should’ve named Sansa queen instead. And it gives us a hint as to how they’ll react when they learn about Jon bending the knee.

Thanks for the ask!
